articles.headline: Gas Prices in U.S. Rise for a Second Week After Refineries Shut Down
articles.snippet: The gains could raise pressure on policymakers, but analysts say the higher prices may be short-lived as refineries in California and Washington restart production.
articles.abstract: The gains could raise pressure on policymakers, but analysts say the higher prices may be short-lived as refineries in California and Washington restart production.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gasoline prices in the United States are creeping higher, reversing a monthslong streak of declines and chipping away at a potent talking point for the Biden administration, which had been emphasizing its success at easing pressure on drivers since the summer.

articles.headline: Herschel Walker Urged Woman to Have a 2nd Abortion, She Says
articles.snippet: The Georgia Senate candidate’s ex-girlfriend says he wanted her to terminate a pregnancy in 2011. She chose to have their son instead.
articles.abstract: The Georgia Senate candidate’s ex-girlfriend says he wanted her to terminate a pregnancy in 2011. She chose to have their son instead.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A woman who has said Herschel Walker, the Republican Senate nominee in Georgia, paid for her abortion in 2009 told The New York Times that he urged her to terminate a second pregnancy two years later. They ended their relationship after she refused.
articles.byline: By Maya King, Lisa Lerer and Jonah E. Bromwich

articles.headline: Nobel Peace Prize Winners Share a Past Shadowed by Russian Abuses
articles.snippet: Democracy advocates from Belarus, Russia and Ukraine were jointly awarded the world’s most prestigious peace prize, an implicit condemnation of the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine and repression at home.
articles.abstract: Democracy advocates from Belarus, Russia and Ukraine were jointly awarded the world’s most prestigious peace prize, an implicit condemnation of the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine and repression at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Nobel Peace Prize was awarded on Friday to human rights advocates in Russia, Ukraine and Belarus whose campaigns for democracy, civil liberties and accountability for crimes of the past represent a sharp challenge to the aggression and repression unleashed by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski, Megan Specia and Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: A Distracted Russia Is Losing Its Grip on Its Old Soviet Sphere
articles.snippet: Russia’s domination of Central Asia and the Caucasus region is unraveling as the Kremlin focuses on the war in Ukraine — and border violence is flaring.
articles.abstract: Russia’s domination of Central Asia and the Caucasus region is unraveling as the Kremlin focuses on the war in Ukraine — and border violence is flaring.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the Kremlin distracted by its flagging war more than 1,500 miles away in Ukraine, Russia’s dominium over its old Soviet empire shows signs of unraveling. Moscow has lost its aura and its grip, creating a disorderly vacuum that previously obedient former Soviet satraps, as well as China, are moving to fill.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Sergey Ponomarev

articles.headline: 4 Weeks Out, Senate Control Hangs in the Balance in Tumultuous Midterms
articles.snippet: The G.O.P. claimed the momentum in the spring. Then the overturning of Roe v. Wade galvanized Democrats. As the momentum shifts again, the final stretch of the 2022 midterms defies predictability.
articles.abstract: The G.O.P. claimed the momentum in the spring. Then the overturning of Roe v. Wade galvanized Democrats. As the momentum shifts again, the final stretch of the 2022 midterms defies predictability.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exactly one month until Election Day, Republicans remain favored to take over the House in November, but momentum in the pitched battle for the Senate has seesawed back and forth as a multimillion-dollar avalanche of advertising has blanketed the top battleground states.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Reid J. Epstein and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Blast on Crimean Bridge Deals Blow to Russian War Effort in Ukraine
articles.snippet: Any impediment to traffic on the bridge could affect Russia’s ability to wage war in southern Ukraine, where Ukraine’s forces have been fighting an increasingly effective counteroffensive.
articles.abstract: Any impediment to traffic on the bridge could affect Russia’s ability to wage war in southern Ukraine, where Ukraine’s forces have been fighting an increasingly effective counteroffensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A fireball consumed two sections of the only bridge linking the occupied Crimean Peninsula to Russia on Saturday, disrupting the most important supply line for Russian troops fighting in southern Ukraine and dealing an embarrassing blow to the Kremlin, which is facing continued losses on the battlefield and mounting criticism at home.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: An American in Ukraine Finds the War He’s Been Searching For
articles.snippet: For an unconventional former Marine colonel, Ukraine represents the morally just war that eluded him his entire career. But how much can he and his military start-up help?
articles.abstract: For an unconventional former Marine colonel, Ukraine represents the morally just war that eluded him his entire career. But how much can he and his military start-up help?

articles.headline: Is There a Future for Late-Night Talk Shows?
articles.snippet: Big changes are coming to the longtime staple of television programming, as the genre struggles to make the leap to the streaming world.
articles.abstract: Big changes are coming to the longtime staple of television programming, as the genre struggles to make the leap to the streaming world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trevor Noah is leaving “The Daily Show” next year. James Corden, the host of CBS’s “The Late Late Show,” will depart his show then as well. TBS canceled “Full Frontal With Samantha Bee” this year.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: Streaming Services Want to Fill the Family Movie Void
articles.snippet: With theatrical releases way down, the streaming giants have been pumping out multigenerational fare, including a number of live-action films.
articles.abstract: With theatrical releases way down, the streaming giants have been pumping out multigenerational fare, including a number of live-action films.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sony Pictures unleashed the singing reptile “Lyle, Lyle Crocodile” in 4,350 theaters across the country this weekend to the tune of an estimated $12 million to $13 million.

articles.headline: How California’s Bullet Train Went Off the Rails
articles.snippet: America’s first experiment with high-speed rail has become a multi-billion-dollar nightmare. Political compromises created a project so expensive that almost no one knows how it can be built as originally envisioned.
articles.abstract: America’s first experiment with high-speed rail has become a multi-billion-dollar nightmare. Political compromises created a project so expensive that almost no one knows how it can be built as originally envisioned.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Building the nation’s first bullet train, which would connect Los Angeles and San Francisco, was always going to be a formidable technical challenge, pushing through the steep mountains and treacherous seismic faults of Southern California with a series of long tunnels and towering viaducts.

articles.headline: Ukrainians Fear Russian Reprisals for Crimea Bridge Attack
articles.snippet: Bitter over a strike against a vital bridge, Moscow hit civilian areas of Ukraine with a barrage of rockets, and some Ukrainians feared worse to come.
articles.abstract: Bitter over a strike against a vital bridge, Moscow hit civilian areas of Ukraine with a barrage of rockets, and some Ukrainians feared worse to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — With some prominent Russians calling for fierce reprisals after an explosion crippled Russia’s sole bridge to Crimea, the Kremlin on Sunday launched a barrage of rockets at Ukrainian civilian areas, sending a deadly reminder that for all its battlefield losses, Moscow can still inflict mass misery.
articles.byline: By Megan Specia, Michael Schwirtz and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: Skepticism, Confusion, Frustration: Inside Mark Zuckerberg’s Metaverse Struggles
articles.snippet: Meta’s push to develop virtual and augmented reality technology has had a bumpy year.
articles.abstract: Meta’s push to develop virtual and augmented reality technology has had a bumpy year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last October, when Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, announced that the company would change its name to Meta and become a “metaverse company,” he sketched a vision of a utopian future many years off in which billions of people would inhabit immersive digital environments for hours on end, working, socializing and playing games inside virtual and augmented worlds.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac, Sheera Frenkel and Kevin Roose

articles.headline: ‘Saved by Grace’: Evangelicals Find a Way Forward With Herschel Walker
articles.snippet: The embattled G.O.P. candidate reportedly paid for an ex-girlfriend’s abortion, but conservatives have learned to tolerate the behavior of those who advance their cause.
articles.abstract: The embattled G.O.P. candidate reportedly paid for an ex-girlfriend’s abortion, but conservatives have learned to tolerate the behavior of those who advance their cause.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Why Little-Noticed State Legislative Races Could Be Hugely Consequential
articles.snippet: Races in state legislatures are often quiet and turn on local issues like roads or schools. But a Supreme Court case could give these legislative bodies nearly absolute power over federal elections.
articles.abstract: Races in state legislatures are often quiet and turn on local issues like roads or schools. But a Supreme Court case could give these legislative bodies nearly absolute power over federal elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: That Reusable Trader Joe’s Bag? It’s Rescuing an Indian Industry.
articles.snippet: India’s deep-rooted jute industry has struggled for decades, undercut by cheaper synthetics. Now its bags are a sought-after biodegradable alternative.
articles.abstract: India’s deep-rooted jute industry has struggled for decades, undercut by cheaper synthetics. Now its bags are a sought-after biodegradable alternative.
articles.lead_paragraph: NADIA, India — When shoppers in places like America take a woven reusable bag to the store, they aren’t just saving the planet. They are reviving a storied industry thousands of miles away in India.

articles.headline: Three Economists, Including Ex-Fed Chair Bernanke, Win Nobel for Work on Bank Crises
articles.snippet: Ben Bernanke, the former Federal Reserve chair, and the economists Douglas Diamond and Philip Dybvig were awarded for their influential work on the relationship between banks and economic turmoil.
articles.abstract: Ben Bernanke, the former Federal Reserve chair, and the economists Douglas Diamond and Philip Dybvig were awarded for their influential work on the relationship between banks and economic turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded on Monday to Ben S. Bernanke, the former Federal Reserve chair, and two other academics who have helped to reshape how the world understands the relationship between banks and financial crises.

articles.headline: As Warehouses Multiply, Some Cities Say: Enough
articles.snippet: Several municipalities in California’s Inland Empire have halted new projects to study their impact on pollution and congestion, but labor and business groups have warned that moratoriums could cost the region tax revenue and jobs.
articles.abstract: Several municipalities in California’s Inland Empire have halted new projects to study their impact on pollution and congestion, but labor and business groups have warned that moratoriums could cost the region tax revenue and jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the front yard of her ranch-style home, Pam Lemos peered out on the vast valley of her childhood.
articles.byline: By Kurtis Lee and Alex Welsh

articles.headline: Boris Johnson Inc. Is About to Go Public
articles.snippet: Following in the footsteps of his predecessors, the former prime minister is likely to earn huge sums as an author and speaker, just as the lecture circuit booms back to life.
articles.abstract: Following in the footsteps of his predecessors, the former prime minister is likely to earn huge sums as an author and speaker, just as the lecture circuit booms back to life.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boris Johnson the politician went bust in July when his Conservative Party colleagues forced him to resign as prime minister. Boris Johnson the business, on the other hand, is about to make a small fortune.
